Alhama – Alhama or La Mala La Malahá the royal salt springs in way. 2000 souls. runs to el saladillo Probably El Saltillo, between Vélez-Málaga and Alhama de Granada. Conder also calls it ‘El Saladillo’, ascribing the name of the spring to the saline taste of its water.. Thence 4 hours to Alhama, city only accessible from west where a castle. 1 500 families. Moors had a revenue of 500 000 ducats from letting XtiansChristians bathe. Alhama to Lamala La Malahá 20 miles. only one small village on road. 8 Leagues to La Venuela. an hour beyond La Venuela La Viñuela Velez Malaga 7000 souls. Drawing: drum

div.note: Summarises and paraphrases Conder, Modern Traveller, vol. 18, pp. 256-67, which itself draws on Townsend, Swinburne, Jacob, Peyron and Bourgoing.
div.ab: Foreign review Nov. 1828 says Moors had no knowledge of classics therefore all their poetry new. all in vulgar tongue. even science in verse & algebra. The rest of Europe wrote then in latin. Many XtiansChristians in Spain wrote in Arabic, many of their books yet at Toledo & Escurial. The clergy menaced XtiansChristians for this. Also Moors wrote a code of Arab laws in Spanish & a book of agriculture. A Spanish MSManuscript. in Arab letters mentiond by M. de Sacy. When Calcanasor i.e. the legendary Battle of Calatañazor, usually dated to 1002 and usually as a Muslim defeat. was taken by Moors in 998. a ghost as a fisherman on the banks of the Guadalquivir sung in a loud & mournful voice “Almanser has lost his drum at Calcanasor”. he sung alternately in Arabic & Spanish & then vanishd. First real Spanish poetry Galician where no Moor. Gonzalo Hermiguez to Ourouana his wife

Many Spanish histories of 12th century. Ferdinand & his Son Alonzo the wise translated code of Goths into Spanish & used Spanish in every thing. But Alphonso read arabic deeply, but ordered that all useful works should be translated into Spanish. The Limousin tongue, says Raymond Vidal an old Troubador was the 3d & principal tongue of Spain used in Guienne & Provence Catalonia Valencia & Islands. Antonio Ruffi historian of Marseilles says tounge of that city changed in 12 century by Catalonian words. [O with X through (Indicating continuation onto next page) Actually summary of Foreign Quarterly Review, vol. 3, no. 5 (Sep 1828), 1-28: review of Silvestre de Sacy, Chrestomathie Arabe..., 2nd edn, 3 vols (Paris, 1826-7). Specifically, pp. 13-18 of the review.
